sub_title: A woman driven by intellectual curiosity | UWCSEA graduate
summary: That mixed kid from the block building a better world through empathy and reason

education.degree_name: Bachelor of Architecture, Urbanism, and Building Sciences [AUBS]

projects.title: EE [SCORED A]: How does promoting gender equality in Sub-Saharan Africa can help to alleviate global hunger?
projects.description:
Extended Essay is the core IBDP coursework that allows students to showcase their passion through an academic investigation beyond the IB curriculum. 

As a UWC idealist, I believe that social justice can drive sustainability and economic development. To test my hypothesis, I studied the agriculture of Sub-Saharan Africa, where gender equality is used a tool to increase the workers' independent access to capital and transform the most severely food insecure population into the stakeholders of resilient food supplies. What can the rest of the world learn from Sub-Saharan Africa? 

Key words: food security, agricultural capital, gender equality in Uganda; Sustainable Development Goals, structural, cultural and direct gender-based violence, cycle of poverty, gender yield gaps

This essay is a world study of Global Politics and Geography, two subjects I did not study in IB. Allowing a student to investigate a subject outside of their expertise is always a great risk for EE supervisors. Allowing a science student to inquire in two humanities outside of her curriculum - that is something unheard of in UWCSEA East before this project. Made possible by two outstanding women, the EE coordinator Uzay Ashton and my essay's supervisor Melanie Wilson, this essay is my tribute towards the prosperous future brought by gender equality. 

Thank you, Ms Wilson and Ms Ashton! 

[Please contact me to view the publication]

contributors.headline: A woman driven by intellectual curiosity | UWCSEA graduate

profile_positions.description:
Mastering English allowed me to move to Singapore on a 165 000 SGD scholarship at the age of 16 and pursue second to none secondary education. I was awarded the privilege to see the world, find myself, create community, and make confident career choices. I am lucky to have parents who invested everything they have into my future. Most Latvian youth doesn’t. 

Through this job, I provide affordable English lessons to students in my home community who wish to live in an international environment.

My students are:
• working professionals in their 30s
• grade 9 students preparing for national exams
• middle schoolers
• elementary students with attention deficit

Open to new connections!
profile_positions.title: English Second Language Tutor

profile_positions.description:
"Clear" is a social skincare app with a mission of making skincare accessible and transparent. 

As a part of the business development team, I devised marketing strategies for the company’s latest product, the Clear Debit Card. Managed through the app, the online MasterCard allows users to get discounts on skincare that is purchased through the app's affiliate links. It can also be used as a regular debit card.

A recommendation from the Clear CEO is available per request.

Through this internship, I learned:
- how to run a start up 
- how to source funding through start up competitions in the US
- digital tools used by tech companies to run teams
profile_positions.title: Business Development Intern

profile_positions.description:
Imagine a Better World
Day 1: Imagine a world of sustainable cities
Day 2: Imagine a world where we pay the true cost of food
Day 3: Imagine a world where we prevent pandemics
Day 4: Imagine a world without violent conflict
Day 5: Building critical skills
profile_positions.title: Summer School Participant

profile_positions.description:
Debuting on the labour market through 10-hour shifts in a beauty salon was far from a dream. Yet, this job that urged me to adapt to a fast changing environment, prioritise, and manage time under pressure. 

I found purpose in the manual labour through human-interaction: be it comforting a client who is distressed by the fancy ambiance of the beauty salon, making their favourite beverage, entertaining their children; or abandoning my direct duties to rush for a lunch takeaway for hairdressers with packed schedules. Surrounded by adults who are immersed in brutal everyday and childish dreams, I grasped the importance of taking care of one another in little things. Putting the extra time to fold and perfectly align all kinds of towels in the hairdressers' and the cosmetologists' favourite ways, housekeeping a master's drawer according to their holy instrument arrangement.

The urge to complete everything on time and well made the job feel like a computer science lesson. 
How do to convert a mixed pile of dried towels into folded columns, so that the towels have no crumbs and match by colour? Remember, ironing is lengthy and you can only fold one towel at a time, not fast enough for towels not to crumple under the pile's weight. 

Solution: 
1. Get a few chairs around: each for a unique towel cover.
2. Open the dryer.
Repeat
3. Take a towel out and hang it flat on the back of its respective chair.
Until
4. The dryer is empty.
For i = 1 to n [insert the number of sorted smooth piles]   
5. Fold a towel and add it to its respective column on a shelf.
End!

Eventually, I developed an algorithm for every duty operation and accounted for the inconsistent client traffic. In times of calm, I sorted and arranged the different types of cups and other barista supplies, so that their reachability is proportional to the percentage frequency of use. The precious time it saved me when 7 coffees and 3 teas are due at the same time.

I am proud of my first job with a mop (^.^)_/ !
profile_positions.title: Hairdresser’s Assistant

volunteer_experiences.description:
Sustainable Living Lab is a sustainability consultancy and innovation lab, founded in Singapore in 2011. We develop impactful, sustainable solutions in line with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. Our expertise is in utilising technology as a lever for sustainability and following a community-driven approach for implementation. Our clients include several Governments, international development organisations, leading MNCs and SMEs. 

As a chair of the SLL’s client NGO Repair Kopitam’s office on UWCSEA East campus, I coached electrical repair and popularised repair culture within the student community

The Plastic Project exists to tackle one of the biggest issues Earth is currently facing: Plastic Pollution.

We are a community-driven organisation dedicated to educate and recycle plastic waste into reusable goods. We are creating products in Singapore to positively impact the planet with education and advocating for a progressive circular economy. 

As a student volunteer, I sorted and processed plastics serve as the raw material for the company’s products and photo documented documented the team’s journey towards a more sustainable Singapore.
